isis.stitle: Recall 97506 - Standard Turn Signal Switch on 2000, 4000, and 8000 Series Tractors and 4000 Series Trucks Coded for 08WAT Turn Signal Switch

recall.subject: Standard Turn Signal Switch on 2000, 4000, and 8000 Series Tractors and 4000 Series Trucks Coded for 08WAT Turn Signal Switch

defect.para: The turn signal switch shoulder bolt that holds the internal switch components together can progressively loosen, resulting in loss of turn signal function. Where this condition exists, it is always preceded by a significant loosening of the turn signal arm and the ability to move the emergency flasher outside of its channel. The loss of turn signal function will be apparent since the turn indicator in the dash will not flash. While a driver must exercise caution at all times to assure that other motorists are clear before executing a turn or lane change, the ability to warn the other motorists of the driver's intention before turning is lost if signal lights do not function. The combination of being unable to warn the motorists with signal lights, plus incorrect action of the part of the driver could cause a vehicular accident that could result in personal injury or property damage, or both.

step1.para:
If the date code number (located on the bottom of the turn signal lever) is higher than 41411, no further action is required.
If the date code number is between 13371 and 41411 and the turn signal lever arm is loose, then continued to step 2 (refer to Figure 1).
Remove plastic cover from switch by pulling bottom of the plastic cover out and up at the tabs ( Figure 1).
Disconnect the harness connector located on the bottom of the switch.
Tighten shoulder bolt to ensure that it is fully seated.

caution.para: Do not apply more than 25-32 in-lbs. (289-360 Ncm) torque; excessive torque will strip the threads.

step1.para: Carefully back the shoulder bolt out two or three turns.

caution.para: The turn signal assembly will come apart when the shoulder bolt is loosened approximately 7 turns.

step1.para: Apply one or two drops of Loctite in the threaded hole where the shoulder bolt threads adjoin to the base threads ( Figure 1).
Re-tighten shoulder bolt to 25 to 32 in-lbs. (280 to 360 Ncm) torque.

caution.para: Do not apply more than 25-32 in-lbs. (289-360 Ncm) torque; excessive torque will strip the threads.

step1.para: Install plastic switch cover, attach harness and mount switch to steering column.

partsinfo.para: Attached to this dealer letter is a poster that must be displayed at the Service Parts counter to notify aftermarket customers of this recall. The poster should be displayed until October 15, 1999. The purchaser of a turn signal switch that is subject to this recall may elect to apply the thread-locking compound, or may elect to have the dealer appy the compound at no charge to the customer.
Loctite 271 or equivalent thread-locking compound (readily available at retail stores).

entry.para: Remove turn signal switch, tighten bolts, apply Loctite and install switch

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

Dealers must correct all vehicles and aftermarket parts subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, until October 15, 1999. The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or turn signal switch or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair the vehicle or aftermarket part as soon as possible.
